user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3 algo3,
                                 const char *username,
                                 const char *realm,
                                 const char *password,
                                 void *userdigest_bin,
                                 size_t bin_buf_size)
{
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  if (! digest_init_one_time (&da, get_base_digest_algo (algo3)))
    return MHD_NO;

  if (digest_get_size (&da) > bin_buf_size)
    ret = MHD_NO;
  else
  {
    calc_userdigest (&da,
                     username,
                     strlen (username),
                     realm,
                     strlen (realm),
                     password,
                     userdigest_bin);
    ret = MHD_YES;

#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
    if (digest_ext_error (&da))
      ret = MHD_NO;
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */
  }
  digest_deinit (&da);

  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
    if (digest_ext_error (&da))
      ret = MHD_NO;
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The conditional block is controlled by the compile-time macro MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR: when the macro is defined the if (digest_ext_error(&da)) ret = MHD_NO; statement is compiled and reachable at runtime; when the macro is not defined the block is removed at pre-processing so there is no unreachable compiled code. This fragment, as written, does not introduce unreachable code. (A hypothetical violation would occur only if such statements appeared after an unconditional return or other guaranteed jump so that compiled code could never be executed—this is not the case here.)
